free_text.Learning outcomes: The course provides an overview of the technologies that are essential for fusion developments and[br/]for industrial plasma applications, highlighting the synergies between the two fields. The aim is to[br/]provide a combined theoretical and experimental backgorund to the various topics, including[br/]vacuum technologies, cryogenics, high current and voltage systems, materials for fusion,[br/]superconducting magnets, control and data acquisition, electrical arcs, plasma fuelling, mm-wave[br/]systems, plasma fuelling and the tritium cycle in fusion reactors. The introductory plasma physics[br/]and fusion courses are a pre-requisite.
free_text.Content: The course will consist of three parts:[br/]1. Common aspects of fusion and industrial plasma technologies[br/]-Vacuum technologies; Cryogenics; Electrical arcs; High current and voltage systems (3 weeks)[br/]2. Specific fusion aspects[br/]-Control and data acquisition (1 week)[br/]-mm-wave sytems (2 weeks)[br/]-Plasma fuelling and tritium cycle (1 week)[br/]-Materials for fusion (3 weeks)[br/]-Superconducting magnets for fusion (2 weeks)[br/]3. Specific industrial plasma applications techniques (2 weeks)
free_text.Required prior knowledge: Basic plasma physics and fusion courses
